Core Concepts¶

New Logic can be expressed in terms of an API that applies Core Concepts to Domain objects.

Believable Choice¶

Believable Choice.

prios_api.concepts.believable_choice.believable_choice(values_and_weights: List[Tuple[StringOrFloat, float]], value_type: prios_api.domain_objects.objects.QuestionType) → Optional[StringOrFloat][source]¶

Believable choice

TODO: Change to ValueType.

Parameters:
  • values_and_weights – Values and Believability weights.
  • value_type – Type of value
Returns:

Value or None. Value represents either the believability-weighted average or the answer choice on which there is

sufficient believability.
Return type:

Optional[StringOrFloat]
prios_api.concepts.believable_choice.believable_choice_categorical_binary(values_and_weights: List[Tuple[str, float]], minimum_vote: float = 0.7) → Optional[str][source]¶

Disagrees With logic for Categorical/Binary responses.

Parameters:
  • values_and_weights – Strings values and corresponding believability
  • minimum_vote – Believable choice has greater than this quantity of the believability-weighted vote.
Returns:

Believable choice, or None (if there isn’t one).
Return type:

Optional[str]

“Believable Choice” logic for Numeric responses.

Parameters:values_and_weights – Numeric values and corresponding believability.
Returns:Believability-weighted average
Return type:float

Divisiveness¶

Divisiveness: Statistic of disagreement between a set of opinions.

prios_api.concepts.divisiveness.divisiveness_stat(values: List[float], value_type: prios_api.domain_objects.objects.QuestionType, map_to_sentiment: bool = True) → float[source]¶

Divisiveness is the standard deviation of opinions.

Parameters:
  • values – Numerical values whose divisiveness is being calculated.
  • value_type – Type of value
  • map_to_sentiment – Map values to positive, neutral, or negative sentiment prior to taking standard deviation. Default is True.
Returns:

Divisiveness measure.
Return type:

float

Polarizing¶

Polarization:

prios_api.concepts.polarizing.is_polarizing(values: List[float], thresh_on_std_scale: float = 1.0, thresh_on_std_mapped_scale: float = 0.5, thresh_on_poles: float = 0.25) → bool[source]¶

“Is polarizing” is a predicate on a distribution of values on the 1-to-10 scale. It returns True if the distribution satisfies three criteria: * Divisiveness statistic (after mapping to sentiment) exceeds thresh_on_std_mapped_scale * Divisiveness statistic (raw values) exceeds thresh_on_std_scale * Polarization statistic exceeds thresh_on_poles

Parameters:
  • values –
  • thresh_on_std_scale –
  • thresh_on_std_mapped_scale –
  • thresh_on_poles –
Returns:

True if the distribution of values satisfies three sets of criteria.
Return type:

bool
prios_api.concepts.polarizing.is_polarizing_v0(values: List[float], thresh_on_std_scale: float = 1.0, thresh_on_std_mapped_scale: float = 0.5, thresh_on_poles: float = 0.25) → bool[source]¶

Is polarizing

Parameters:
  • scale_assertions – List of assertions with scale values.
  • thresh_on_std_scale – Threshold on standard deviation of scale values.
  • thresh_on_std_mapped_scale – Threshold on standard deviation of scale values mapped to 1, 2, and 3
  • thresh_on_poles – Threshold on ratio between poles
Returns:

Whether a set of scale values are polarizing.
Return type:

bool
prios_api.concepts.polarizing.polarizing_stat(values: List[float]) → float[source]¶

Returns the polarization statistic, which measures the balance between positive opinions and negative opinions.

It is the minimum of ratio of the number of positive opinions to the number of negative opinions and the ratio of the number of negative opinions to the number of positive opinions.

Parameters:values – List of values
Returns:Polarization statistic.
Return type:float

Synthesis¶

prios_api.concepts.synthesis.synthesize(values: List[float], synthesis_fun: Callable = <function weighted_average>) → Optional[float][source]¶

Synthesize values into a :param values: Numerical values that are being synthesized into a single number. :param synthesis_fun: Operation applied to synthesize a list of values.

Returns:Synthesized value. Returns None if there aren’t any values.
Return type:float

Examples

>>> synthesize([])
>>> synthesize([1, 1, 1, 2, 5])
2.0
>>> import numpy as np
>>> synthesize([1, 1, 1, 2, 5], np.median)
1.0
